{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox monastery | image = | caption = Tzu Chi's [[Nelumbo nucifera|lotus]] Logo. | name = Tzu Chi Foundation | full = Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan | native_name = 慈濟基金會 | native_name_lang = zh | established = 14 May 1966 | order = [[Mahayana]] | founder = [[Cheng Yen]] | abbot = [[Cheng Yen]] | location = [[Hualien City|Hualien]], [[Taiwan]] | coord = | public_access = | other_info = |website={{url|http://tw.tzuchi.org/en}}}} {{Infobox Chinese | t = 財團法人中華民國佛教慈濟慈善事業基金會 | s = 财团法人中华民国佛教慈济慈善事业基金会 | bpmf = ㄘㄞˊㄊㄨㄢˊㄈㄚˇㄖㄣˊㄓㄨㄥ ㄏㄨㄚˊㄇㄧㄣˊㄍㄨㄛˊㄈㄛˊㄐㄧㄠˋㄘˊㄐㄧˋㄘˊㄕㄢˋㄕˋㄧㄝˋㄐㄧ ㄐㄧㄣ ㄏㄨㄟˋ | p = Cáituán Fǎrén Zhōnghuá Mínguó Fójiào Cí Jì Císhàn Shìyè Jījīn Huì | altname = Short name | t2 = 慈濟基金會 | s2 = 慈济基金会 | p2 = Cí jì jījīn huì | poj2 = Chû-chè ki-kim-hōe }} {{buddhism}}
'''Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Republic of China''', known for short as the '''Tzu Chi Foundation''' ({{lang-zh|t=慈濟基金會}}; literally "Compassionate Relief"), is a Taiwanese international humanitarian and non-governmental organization (NGO) with over 10 million members worldwide throughout 47 countries. It is operated by a worldwide network of volunteers and employees and has been awarded a special consultative status at the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]].<ref>O'Neill, Mark (2010), ''[http://www.books.com.tw/exep/assp.php/jamezku/products/F012089631 Tzu Chi: Serving With Compassion]'', John Wiley & Sons</ref>
The Tzu Chi Foundation was founded by Master [[Cheng Yen]], a Taiwanese Buddhist nun, or ''[[bhikkhuni]]'', in 1966 as a Buddhist humanitarian organization. The foundation has several sub-organizations such as the Tzu Chi International Medical Association (TIMA) and also the Tzu Chi Collegiate Youth Association (Tzu Ching) (慈濟大專青年聯誼會 (慈青)), Tzu Chi volunteers and relief workers are mostly recognizable worldwide by their blue and white uniforms called, in {{zh|s=藍天白雲}}, ''lántiān báiyún'', ( lit. 'blue sky, white clouds'). The foundation's work includes medical aid, disaster relief, and environmental work such as recycling.
While Tzu Chi has a policy of being secular in its humanitarian work, [[Dharma (Buddhism)|Dharma]] teachings are often integrated into its practices for volunteers. Cheng Yen is considered to be one of the "[[Buddhism in Taiwan|Four Heavenly Kings]]" of Taiwanese Buddhism, and Tzu Chi itself is considered to be one of the "Four Great Mountains", or four major Buddhist organizations of Taiwanese Buddhism along with [[Fo Guang Shan]], [[Dharma Drum Mountain]], and [[Chung Tai Shan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://info.taiwan.net.tw/tourbusE/december_page1.html |title=Come to Taiwan, Return with good memories |publisher=Info.taiwan.net.tw |date= |accessdate=2012-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227183910/http://info.taiwan.net.tw/tourbusE/december_page1.html |archivedate=27 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shuai|first=J. J.|last2=Chen|first2=H. C.|last3=Chang|first3=C. H.|date=2010-12-01|title=Visualization of the Taiwaness Buddhism web based on social network analysis|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5685523/|journal=2010 International Computer Symposium (ICS2010)|pages=187–191|doi=10.1109/COMPSYM.2010.5685523|access-date=2 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905002624/http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5685523/|archive-date=5 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wvGWJcQ3ZX0C&dq=four+heavenly+kings+taiwan+tzu+chi&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=four+heavenly+kings+|title=2600 Years of Sambuddhatva: Global Journey of Awakening|last=|first=|date=2011-01-01|publisher=|year=|isbn=9789559349334|location=|pages=282|language=en|access-date=4 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170410133539/https://books.google.com/books?id=wvGWJcQ3ZX0C&dq=four+heavenly+kings+taiwan+tzu+chi&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=four+heavenly+kings+|archive-date=10 April 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==History==
The Tzu Chi Foundation was founded as a charity organization with [[Buddhist]] origins by the Buddhist nun Master [[Cheng Yen]] on 14 May 1966 in [[Hualien City|Hualien]], Taiwan. She was inspired by her master and mentor, the late Venerable Master [[Yin Shun]] (印順導師, Yìn Shùn dǎoshī) a proponent of [[Humanistic Buddhism]], who exhorted her to "work for Buddhism and for all sentient beings". The organization began with a motto of "instructing the rich and saving the poor" as a group of thirty [[housewives]] who saved fifty [[New Taiwan dollar|cents]] ([[US$]]0.02) every day and stored them in bamboo savings banks to donate to needy families.<ref name="parabola">{{cite web|url=http://www.parabola.org/the-desire-to-relieve-all-suffering|title=THE DESIRE TO RELIEVE ALL SUFFERING|date=2010|publisher=Parabola Magazine|last1=Wolkstein|first1=Diane|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923002225/http://www.parabola.org/the-desire-to-relieve-all-suffering|archivedate=23 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Biography of Dharma Master Cheng Yen|url=http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=159%3Aintroduction&catid=81%3Aabout&Itemid=198&lang=en|website=tw.tzuchi.org|accessdate=15 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823142309/http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=159%3Aintroduction&catid=81%3Aabout&Itemid=198&lang=en|archive-date=23 August 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Tzu Chi experienced modest growth in the first two decades of its establishment, it grew to 293 members in 1968 and by 1986 had just 8,000 members. However, with the surge in popularity of [[Humanistic Buddhism]] in Taiwan in the late 1980s and 1990s, Tzu Chi enjoyed a rapid expansion in membership alongside several other major Taiwanese Buddhist organizations. From 1987 to 1991, Tzu Chi membership doubled in size each year, by 1994, it boasted a membership of 4 million members.<ref name="chinaperspectives.revues.org">{{cite journal|last1=Schak|first1=David|last2=Hsiao|first2=Hsin-Huang Michael|title=Taiwan's Socially Engaged Buddhist Groups|journal=China Perspectives|date=2005|issue=59|url=https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/2803#tocto1n1|accessdate=15 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012062338/https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/2803#tocto1n1|archive-date=12 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Tzu Chi has grown to become a significant actor in civil society, Tzu Chi is not only the largest Buddhist organization in Taiwan,<ref name="chinaperspectives.revues.org2">{{cite journal|last1=Schak|first1=David|last2=Hsiao|first2=Hsin-Huang Michael|date=2005|title=Taiwan's Socially Engaged Buddhist Groups|url=https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/2803#tocto1n1|journal=China Perspectives|issue=59|accessdate=15 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012062338/https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/2803#tocto1n1|archive-date=12 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> but also Taiwan's largest owner of private land.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=2698712|title=Why Tzu Chi is sparking resentment|date=6 March 2016|accessdate=15 September 2016|agency=Central News Agency|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915192203/http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=2698712|archive-date=15 September 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The foundation achieved much media attention in Taiwan in 2015 with a controversial plan to develop a plot of land in [[Neihu District]] into a disaster relief center and cultural park.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201503160028.aspx|title=City officials, Neihu residents welcome Tzu Chi's project pullback {{!}} Society {{!}} FOCUS TAIWAN - CNA ENGLISH NEWS|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2015/03/17/2003613729|title=Tzu Chi retracts controversial project - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> The project led to the destruction of parts of the Neihu conservation zone and a public outcry in Taiwan that forced the foundation to end the planned development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2015/03/11/2003613258/1|title=Tzu Chi’s Neihu land should be rejuvenated - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414225114/http://chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/local/taipei/2015/03/17/431281/City-officials.htm|title=City officials, Neihu residents welcome Tzu Chi retreat from project - The China Post|date=2015-04-14|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> The incident led to widespread critical coverage of Tzu Chi by the Taiwanese media, and scrutiny into its finances.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2013/01/24/2003553308|title=Tzu Chi buildings spark protests - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2015/03/17/2003613729|title=Tzu Chi retracts controversial project - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150324231306/http://chinapost.com.tw/editorial/taiwan-issues/2015/03/22/431650/Tzu-Chi.htm|title=Tzu Chi needs more transparency in charity work - The China Post|date=2015-03-24|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414173534/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?cid=1103&MainCatID=&id=20150319000091|title=Tzu Chi in Tainan school land rental subsidy controversy｜WantChinaTimes.com|date=2015-04-14|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> During this time several [[Fake news|unsubstantiated reports]] circulated in Taiwan about the foundation, including unfounded claims that the foundation invested in tobacco and weapons companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414173530/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20150322000132&cid=1701|title=Tzu Chi has admitted errors; it's time for compassion｜WantChinaTimes.com|date=2015-04-14|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> Despite authorities not finding any illicit activity with its finances, calls for greater transparency were made.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20150303000052&cid=1103|title=Tzu Chi Foundation urged to publish detailed donation list|last=|first=|date=|work=Want China Times|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414173317/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20150303000052&cid=1103|archive-date=14 April 2015}}</ref>
As of 2013, the organization was estimated to have approximately 10 million members worldwide, and chapters in 47 countries.<ref name=":34">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PzdyNvcRTWk|title=Master Cheng Yen and Tzu Chi|publisher=The Discovery Channel|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=":02">{{cite web|url=http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=293&Itemid=283&lang=en|title=Tzu Chi Missions|website=tw.tzuchi.org|accessdate=15 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109072414/http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=293&Itemid=283&lang=en|archive-date=9 November 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Organization == The four major causes of Tzu Chi are ''Charity'', ''Medicine'', ''Education'', and ''Humanity'', as highlighted by the official motto, or concept of "Four endeavors, eight footprints" ({{zh|t=四大志業，八大腳印}}). The eight footprints are [[charity (practice)|charity]] causes, medical contributions, [[education]] development, humanities, international disaster assistance, bone-marrow donation, community volunteerism, and environmental protection.
The official website for the organization states that the organization started with Charity, and then extended its aims to include Medicine, Education and Culture. Its stated goal is to promote "sincerity, integrity, trust, and honesty".<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=293&Itemid=283&lang=en|title=Tzu Chi Missions|website=tw.tzuchi.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109072414/http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=293&Itemid=283&lang=en|archive-date=9 November 2016|dead-url=no|accessdate=15 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Tzu Chi is notably distinct from the other "Four Great Mountains" and the other major [[Buddhism in Taiwan|Buddhist organizations of Taiwan]] in respect to three main unique characteristics. First of all, the founder of the organization is a female. Secondly, the founder is not a Buddhist scholar who promotes a specific interpretation of Buddhism nor started any kind of religious movement. And finally, the organization is officially a charitable organization and Tzu Chi itself focuses primarily on humanitarianism and community service rather than Buddhist spiritual development.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hsin-Huang Michael|first1=Hsiao|last2=Schak|first2=David|date=2005|title=Taiwan’s Socially Engaged Buddhist Groups|url=https://chinaperspectives.revues.org/2803#tocto2n6|dead-url=no|journal=China Perspectives|issue=59|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815194230/http://chinaperspectives.revues.org/2803#tocto2n6|archive-date=15 August 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Logo===
Consisting of a ship that also simultaneously bears the lotus fruit and flower, the Tzu Chi logo symbolizes that the world can be made a better place by planting good karmic seeds. Followers believe that these seeds are required for flowers bloom and bear fruit, which is a metaphor for their beliefs that a better society can be created with good actions and pure thoughts. The ship represents Tzu Chi steering a ship of compassion, representing their goal in saving all beings that suffer, while the Eight Petals represent the [[Noble Eightfold Path]] in [[Buddhism]], which Tzu Chi uses as their guide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tzuchi.us/blog/tzu-chi-logo/|title=Tzu Chi Logo - Tzu Chi USA|website=www.tzuchi.us|access-date=2017-07-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709005113/https://www.tzuchi.us/blog/tzu-chi-logo/|archive-date=9 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The Noble Eightfold Path consists of: # [[View (Buddhism)|Right View]] # [[Noble Eightfold Path#Right resolve|Right Thought]] # [[Noble Eightfold Path#Right speech|Right Speech]] # [[Noble Eightfold Path#Right action|Right Action]] # [[Noble Eightfold Path#Right livelihood|Right Livelihood]] # [[Noble Eightfold Path#Right effort|Right Effort]] # [[Sati (Buddhism)|Right Mindfulness]] # [[Right concentration|Right Focus]]
===Tzu Chi's Ten Precepts=== [[File:The Great Awakened of the Universe (宇宙大覺著) is the depiction of Buddha of Tzu Chi Foundation. In the statue, Buddha is letting the world witness his enlightenment.jpg|thumb|Tzu Chi Foundation's depiction of the Buddha on a wall mural. The image is known as "The Great Awakened of the Universe (宇宙大覺著)".]]Tzu Chi also has its own customized version of the [[Five Precepts|Buddhist Precepts]] as formulated by Master Cheng-Yen. The Ten Precepts of Tzu Chi are:
#No killing # No stealing # No fornication # No lying # No drinking # No smoking or use of narcotics or [[betel nuts]] # No gambling # Practice [[filial piety]] and develop pleasant manners and speech # Abide by traffic laws # No participation in political activities or demonstrations
Master Cheng-Yen has stated that she developed these rules based on the new needs of modern society.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ten Precepts of Tzu Chi|url=http://www.tzuchi.net/TCSC.nsf/0adbb3db1b96266f48256ae00021f8ae/9991505677819b0b48256ae8006b85c2|website=tzuchi.net|accessdate=3 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911071105/http://www.tzuchi.net/TCSC.nsf/0adbb3db1b96266f48256ae00021f8ae/9991505677819b0b48256ae8006b85c2|archive-date=11 September 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ===The Great Awakened of the Universe=== The Great Awakened of the Universe (宇宙大覺著) is the Tzu Chi Foundation's depiction of the Buddha. In the statue, the Buddha is depicted as a monk, with his palm placed over a globe, letting the world witness his enlightenment. The image has been subject to controversy in Taiwan, the primary criticism being that the image looks more like Cheng Yen rather than a traditional depiction of [[Gautama Buddha]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}
== Medical Mission == One of the first major initiatives Tzu Chi took part in was the "Tzu Chi Medical Mission". This effort was inspired in 1970 after Cheng Yen noticed a link between poverty and illness after spending six years among the poor of eastern Taiwan.
Tzu Chi's first medical outreach occurred in 1972 when a free clinic was opened in [[Hualien City|Hualien]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://olbios.org/life-of-the-mother-teresa-of-asia/|title=Life of the "Mother Teresa of Asia" {{!}} Olbios|date=2016-01-26|work=Olbios|access-date=2017-03-18|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170319115145/http://olbios.org/life-of-the-mother-teresa-of-asia/|archive-date=19 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Tzu Chi Hospital === [[File:Hualien Tzu Chi General Hospital.JPG|thumb|Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien in 2011]] The Foundation established its first Tzu Chi Hospital in [[Hualien City|Hualien]] in 1986. A 600-bed general hospital had been planned in 1979 to service the impoverished eastern coast of Taiwan. A primary concern for Cheng Yen was that the area was isolated and the people in the area were cut off from aid during disasters.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t--23FOImmIC&dq=Tzu+Chi:+Serving+with+Compassion.&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Tzu Chi: Serving with Compassion.|last=Mark.|first=O'Neill,|date=2010-01-01|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=|isbn=9780470825679|location=|pages=26|oclc=940634655}}</ref> Despite setbacks both in funding for the hospital and finding an acceptable site. Ground was broken on the site eventually chosen on 5 February 1983 at a ceremony officiated by then Provincial Governor (later President) [[Lee Teng-Hui]]. However, two weeks after ground was broken, Cheng Yen received a notice from the military telling her that the property was needed by the military and that construction would have to stop.<ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=http://www.tzuchi.com.tw/en/index.php/history/7-hualien-tzu-chi-hospital|title=Hualien Tzu Chi Hospital|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2017-03-19|language=en-gb|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320052400/http://www.tzuchi.com.tw/en/index.php/history/7-hualien-tzu-chi-hospital|archive-date=20 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XtDRTLTwD88C&dq=The+Life+and+Teachings+of+Venerable+Master+Cheng+Yen&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Challenges The Life and Teachings of Venerable Master Cheng Yen|last=Gary|first=Ho,|date=2014-01-01|publisher=Harbour Publishing|year=|isbn=9781553659921|location=|pages=44|oclc=957463283}}</ref>
A new site was obtained for the hospital with help from Minister of the Interior Lin Yang-kang.<ref name=":23">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t--23FOImmIC&dq=Tzu+Chi:+Serving+with+Compassion.&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Tzu Chi: Serving with Compassion.|last=Mark.|first=O'Neill,|date=2010-01-01|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=|isbn=9780470825679|location=|pages=28|oclc=940634655}}</ref> A second groundbreaking occurred on 2 April 1984 at the new site.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://eng.tzuchi.my/index.php/culture/culture-news-k2/item/7498-50-years-of-tzu-chi-looking-back-and-striding-forward|title=50 Years of Tzu Chi: Looking Back and Striding Forward|access-date=2017-03-19|language=en-gb|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320052417/http://eng.tzuchi.my/index.php/culture/culture-news-k2/item/7498-50-years-of-tzu-chi-looking-back-and-striding-forward|archive-date=20 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The publicity of the project to build the hospital led to a significant increase in the number of Tzu Chi volunteers, with Tzu Chi membership increasing six-fold by the time of the second groundbreaking since the announcement of the project in 1979.<ref name=":23" /> Construction was completed and the hospital opened on 17 August 1986.<ref name=":13" />
Tzu Chi has since built hospitals in [[Yuli, Hualien|Yuli]], Hualien County; [[Dalin, Chiayi|Dalin]], [[Jiayi County]]; [[Guanshan, Taitung|Guanshan]], [[Taidong County]]; [[Tanzi District]], [[Taichung City]]; and [[Xindian District|Xindian]], [[New Taipei City]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W4PuparQrsUC&pg=PA94&dq=tzu+chi+hospitals+yuli&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiw8tmw58jTAhUX22MKHWETDrkQ6AEIJzAB#v=onepage&q=tzu%20chi%20hospitals%20yuli&f=false|title=The Politics of Buddhist Organizations in Taiwan, 1989-2003: Safeguard the Faith, Build a Pure Land, Help the Poor|last=Laliberté|first=André|date=2013-08-21|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9781134353545|location=|pages=94|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://app.tzuchi.com.tw/tzuchi_en/About_TP_Center/Default.htm|title=About Medicine Mission|last=|first=|date=|website=Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital|access-date=28 April 2017}}</ref>
In addition to building hospitals the [[Tzu Chi College of Nursing]] was founded on 17 September 1989 in Hualien in order to address the shortage of nurses on Taiwan's east coast, with a focus on serving the poor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tzuchimedicalfoundation.org/about-tzu-chi/tzu-chi-missions/|title=Tzu Chi Missions|date=2014-12-03|work=BUDDHIST TZU CHI MEDICAL FOUNDATION|access-date=2017-04-29|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170429025148/http://www.tzuchimedicalfoundation.org/about-tzu-chi/tzu-chi-missions/|archive-date=29 April 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4dlOAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA127&dq=tzu+chi+nursing+college&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi20pP28sjTAhUI9WMKHSOUBDYQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=tzu%20chi%20nursing%20college&f=false|title=Ecofeminism and Globalization: Exploring Culture, Context, and Religion|last=Eaton|first=|last2=Lorentzen|date=2004-09-08|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|year=|isbn=9780585482767|location=|pages=127|language=en}}</ref> It was the first private nursing college in Taiwan to waive tuition for selected courses, in addition to providing full scholarships for qualified [[Taiwan aborigine]] students.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}

=== College of Medicine === Tzu Chi established the [[Tzu Chi College of Medicine]] in 1994. This college became [[Tzu Chi University]] in 2000. In the meantime Cheng-Yen appealed to the Taiwanese public to donate their bodies for medical training, attempting to dispel traditional taboos in the process. As a result of this appeal, public support for [[Body donation|body donations]] surged nationwide. Consequently, at the Tzu Chi College of Medicine, there is one body for every four students to study as opposed to one body for every two hundred students at one school, the ratio is the lowest in the country.
In 1995, the Athletic Drug Testing Center was established at the request of the Ministry of Education and went into operation in 1996 during a national sporting event when gold medal winners were tested for banned drugs.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}
== Disaster relief == Tzu Chi is most well known for its disaster relief efforts worldwide. In carrying out these projects, Tzu Chi has a policy that forbids public gatherings for the sole purpose of specific political, economic, and religious groups.<ref>Tzu Chi FAQs, http://www.us.tzuchi.org/usa/images/other/TzuChiFAQ-global.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725233133/http://www.us.tzuchi.org/usa/images/other/TzuChiFAQ-global.pdf |date=25 July 2011 }}</ref> Tzu Chi volunteers are not to discuss business, politics, or preach religion while giving aid.<ref name=":25">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t--23FOImmIC&dq=Tzu+Chi:+Serving+with+Compassion.&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Tzu Chi: Serving with Compassion.|last=Mark.|first=O'Neill,|date=2010-01-01|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=|isbn=9780470825679|location=|pages=28|oclc=940634655}}</ref> One of the most iconic attributes of Tzu Chi disaster relief efforts is that volunteers not only provide short term aid but also partake in long term projects to rebuild the communities affected. Tzu Chi often builds new homes, schools, hospitals, and places of worship (including churches and mosques for non-Buddhists) for victims following a disaster.<ref>{{Citation|last=|title=Dharma Master Cheng Yen - Discovery Channel Documentary 證嚴法師 - Discovery 頻道 (中文字幕) 480p|date=2014-03-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SHsDjv5JqbU|accessdate=2017-04-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525233639/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SHsDjv5JqbU|archive-date=25 May 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===People's Republic of China===
Tzu Chi's involvement with providing aid in the People's Republic of China was difficult at first. Cheng Yen has referred to relief work in [[China]] as "Building a Bridge of Love." The initial problems with providing aid in China involved the [[Cross-Strait relations|political tensions]] between Taiwan and China and Communist China's disdain for religion. In Taiwan, it was difficult to convince [[Taiwanese people|Taiwanese]] to help the [[Chinese people|Chinese]], and in China, it was difficult to convince government officials normally wary of religious organizations to accept Tzu Chi.
Tzu Chi's involvement in the [[People's Republic of China]] began in 1991, when it undertook relief operations after [[Eastern China flood of 1991|severe floods hit central and eastern China]]. The aid provided to China was Tzu Chi's first major effort at international relief aid, it also allowed Tzu Chi to develop its principles of delivering aid and establish relations with the People's Republic of China. Since then, the foundation has built schools, nursing homes and entire villages, including infrastructure in poor inland areas, such as [[Guizhou]] province.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Outline of assistance given to Chinese provinces|url=http://taipei.tzuchi.org.tw/tzquart/book/book1/book1.htm|archivedate=2012-03-05|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305053915/http://taipei.tzuchi.org.tw/tzquart/book/book1/book1.htm|accessdate=2014-03-27}}</ref>
Over the past twenty years, Tzu Chi expanded their humanitarian work and influence to 28 provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions in China. Projects include relief work after major disasters like the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake|Sichuan earthquake]]; distribution of rice and goods to the poor; social programs like regular visits to the needy; [[scholarship]] programs to the less privileged students; medical missions like [[bone marrow donation]] and [[free clinics]]; and educational outings of environmental protection and recycling activities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=647%3Atzu-chi-opens-chinas-dirst-overseas-ngo-office&catid=77%3Amissionofcharity&Itemid=177&lang=en|title=Tzu Chi Opens China's 1st Overseas NGO Office|date=23 August 2010|publisher=Tzu Chi|access-date=30 January 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721184701/http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=647:tzu-chi-opens-chinas-dirst-overseas-ngo-office&catid=77:missionofcharity&Itemid=177&lang=en|archive-date=21 July 2011|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In March 2008, Tzu Chi became the first organization represented by a non-Mainland resident to be registered with the Chinese government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/03/11/us-china-taiwan-religion-idUSPEK23024220080311|title=Atheist China gives nod to Taiwan Buddhist group|date=11 March 2008|publisher=Reuters|access-date=2 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924131857/http://www.reuters.com/article/2008/03/11/us-china-taiwan-religion-idUSPEK23024220080311|archive-date=24 September 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In the aftermath of the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]], Tzu Chi sent food, blankets and medical aid to survivors, while volunteers in China set out for the disaster zone.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2008/05/16/156647/p2/Jets-lift.htm|title=Jets lift life-saving aid materials to Sichuan|publisher=[[The China Post]]|access-date=30 === Aid in Taiwan === In 1996, Tzu Chi started a nationwide volunteer program where volunteers are registered according to where they live with the goal of "neighbors helping neighbors." The community volunteer initiative began as a disaster relief effort started in response to [[Typhoon Herb]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/local/archives/1999/10/03/0000004923|title=Tzuchi always ready to lend a helping hand - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=379:the-world-is-impermanent&catid=82:miscellaneous&Itemid=326&lang=en|title=The World is Impermanent|last=Foundation|first=Tzu Chi|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en-gb|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171015162351/http://tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=379%3Athe-world-is-impermanent&catid=82%3Amiscellaneous&Itemid=326&lang=en|archive-date=15 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tzuchi.org.sg/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=645&Itemid=566|title=Community Volunteers|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tzuchi.org.sg|language=en-gb|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810185022/http://www.tzuchi.org.sg/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=645&Itemid=566|archive-date=2016-08-10|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref>
Tzu Chi volunteers were one of the first responders in the [[1999 Jiji earthquake|Jiji earthquake]] (known in Taiwan as the 921 earthquake) of 1999, mobilizing within 2 hours to provide thousands of sets of food and relief supplies to victims. The volunteers followed a strict system of organization where commissioners and teams of volunteers were assigned to specific townships, and teams were assigned to specific areas within the townships. This organizational structure was what allowed the volunteers to be mobilized so quickly and efficiently.<ref>{{Cite === International Disaster Relief === Tzu Chi has participated in numerous other relief projects around the world, including sending teams to [[Indonesia]] and [[Sri Lanka]] in the wake of the [[tsunami]] resulting from the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]] as well as to [[Pakistan]] after the [[2005 Kashmir earthquake|2005 earthquake]] in their northern mountains. The later was done despite poor relations between the governments of the two countries.
In the aftermath of [[Hurricane Sandy]], the organization announced on 18 November 2012 a donation of $10 million in the form of $300 and $600 [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] debit cards to those affected in the [[New York (state)|New York]] and New Jersey area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qgazette.com/news/2012-11-28/Front_Page/Liu_Announces_Buddhist_Tzu_Chi_Donation_Of_10_Mill.html|title=Liu, Announces Buddhist Tzu Chi Donation Of $10 Million|date=28 November 2012|publisher=[[The Queens Gazette]]|accessdate=4 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121209064352/http://www.qgazette.com/news/2012-11-28/Front_Page/Liu_Announces_Buddhist_Tzu_Chi_Donation_Of_10_Mill.html|archive-date=9 December 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Volunteers handed out these cards in parts of [[Brooklyn]], [[Queens]], and [[Staten Island]]. Tzu Chi was also active in providing aid following the [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake|2015 Nepal Earthquake]]. Tzu Chi was also active in relief efforts during [[Hurricane Harvey]] in 2017, the group provided aid, as well as cash gifts for those who helped the community during the disaster.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abc13.com/buddhists-come-to-aid-of-officers-hit-by-harvey/2433855/|title=Buddhists come to aid of officers hit by Harvey|last=Carson|first=Ilona|date=2017-09-20|work=ABC13 effort|last=Broady|first=Arlinda|website=ajc|access-date=2017-10-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005154535/http://www.ajc.com/news/local/hurricane-relief-effort/Op6XVN0u36UWqUgShrE8YP/|archive-date=5 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2017/09/15/appreciation-frustration-harvey-evacuees-dallas/|title=Appreciation Turns To Frustration For Some Harvey Evacuees In Dallas|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005151229/http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2017/09/15/appreciation-frustration-harvey-evacuees-dallas/|archive-date=5 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2016, the organization distributed in the United States over $2 million in cash cards to disaster victims.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lionsroar.com/buddhist-organization-tzu-chi-distributing-humanitarian-relief-in-houston-after-hurricane-harvey/|title=Buddhist organization Tzu Chi distributing humanitarian September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As of 2015, Tzu Chi has provided disaster relief aid to over 85 countries worldwide.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5BaMBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA28&dq=tzu+chi+disaster+relief&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXn77TtcrTAhVI8GMKHSJIC1sQ6AEIMTAC#v=onepage&q=85%20countries&f=false|title=Taiwan's Marginalized Role in International Security: Paying a Price|last=Glaser|first=Bonnie S.|last2=Vitello|first2=Jacqueline A.|date=2015-01-21|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=|isbn=9781442240605|location=|pages=28|language=en}}</ref>
==Global presence== Tzu Chi's headquarters is in [[Hualien County]], Taiwan. <gallery> File:Jing Si Abode.jpg|Jing Si Abode (静思精舍) of Tzu Chi Foundation File:Tzu Chi Foundation Facade, Hualien (3990381753).jpg|The Hall of Still Thoughts. The Tzu Chi General Hospital is on the right File:Tzu Chi Foundation (Hong Kong).jpg|Tzu-Chi Foundation in Hong Kong File:The usual set up for the Tzu Chi 3-in-1 Celebration (浴佛典禮).jpg|The usual set up for the Tzu Chi 3-in-1 Celebration (浴佛典禮) </gallery>
===Portfolios===
Tzu Chi's portfolios include case management, medical, educational and [[disaster relief]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Tzu Chi Foundation Finds Good Karma in Disaster Relief and Preparedness|url=https://www.nyredcross.org/?nd=news_room_detail&news_id=53&jid=63915|publisher=[[American Red Cross]]|accessdate=14 October 2012|date=23 October 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121228094810/https://www.nyredcross.org/?nd=news_room_detail&news_id=53&jid=63915|archivedate=28 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The organization builds and operates many hospitals and schools, with outreach efforts that range from visits to nursing homes to providing bone marrow surgery, as well as offering items such as washing machines to struggling single mothers. The television "Da Ai" network operates with its own news and television programming. Chinese schools have also been established abroad, such as in Australia and the United States, which apart from teaching Chinese and [[sign language]] also guides students in ways of compassion and [[community service]].
===Recycling===
A significant fraction of funds raised by Tzu Chi revolves around [[environmentally friendly]] goals in encouraging the recycling of items such as water bottles as well as using reusable items or reusing items to reduce waste.
As of 2014, the foundation operates over 5,600 recycling stations.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-taiwan-recycling-20141117-story.html|title=Taiwan Buddhists transform plastic waste|last=Jennings|first=Ralph|date=17 Nov 2014|website=latimes.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116175356/http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-taiwan-recycling-20141117-story.html|archive-date=16 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> One of the foundation's projects is the recycling of [[polyethylene terephthalate]] (PET) plastic bottles for the production of textiles. The project, which was started in 2006, collects PET plastic bottles and recycles them into cloth.<ref>Tzu Chi Quarterly, Winter 2008</ref> The project is handled by the Tzu Chi sponsored non-profit Da Ai Technology Co. The products are all designed by members of the paid staff and recycled plastic bottles make up about half of the raw materials for the products. The project collects about 2,000 tons of plastic bottles each year.<ref name=":2" /> Tzu Chi's recycling centers have been a source of criticism however, with critics arguing that Tzu Chi's recycling efforts result in lost income for poor trash collectors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/04/23/2003588703|title=Tzu Chi said to steal from poor - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref>
Since 2007, the foundation has produced over 460,000 polyester blankets out of recycled plastic bottles, many of which have been distributed as part of Tzu Chi's disaster relief programs throughout the world. Other items made with the recycled resins include thermal underwear, T-shirts, hospital bed sheets, medical gowns, suitcases, stuffed animals and uniforms for Tzu Chi volunteers. While the project relies on recycled plastic bottles for the production of its products, its leaders have stated that it is still best for people to not use plastic bottles at all.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=300:a-greener-blanket&catid=59:internationalrelief&Itemid=183&lang=en|title=A Greener Blanket|last=Foundation|first=Tzu Chi|access-date=2017-01-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927052415/http://www.tw.tzuchi.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=300:a-greener-blanket&catid=59:internationalrelief&Itemid=183&lang=en|archive-date=27 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://phys.org/news/2013-03-taiwan-plastic-junk-blankets-dolls.html|title=Taiwan turns plastic junk into blankets, dolls|access-date=2017-01-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116183046/https://phys.org/news/2013-03-taiwan-plastic-junk-blankets-dolls.html|archive-date=16 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
===Dharma===
The teachings of the [[Buddha]] and founder Master Cheng Yen play a core role in the workings of the organization. "Tzu Chi Day" is celebrated every year on the second Sunday of May which generally coincides with the Buddha's birthday ([[Vesak Day]]), and [[Mother's Day]] (as recognised in Taiwan). Celebrations during Tzu Chi Day include the bathing of the Buddha ceremony, the tradition's message is that it is the people that need cleansing before they become better individuals. Tzu Chi promotes many of the teachings of Buddhism, in particular the [[Lotus Sutra]], and also has sutra adaptations through the use of sign language on the [[Innumerable Meanings Sutra|Sutra of the Innumerable Meanings]], which teaches that sentient existence is challenging and filled with disasters in the absence of observations of [[Śīla|virtue]], as well as the [[Water Repentence|Sutra of the Water Repentance]], which advocates and symbolizes the need to repent [[karma|karmic transgressions]]. Despite these activities, Tzu Chi has a policy of not proselytizing religion directly at its public activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/visit-to-the-tzu-chi-foundation-in-taiwan/238309/|title=Visit to the Tzu Chi Foundation in Taiwan - The Manila Times Online|website=www.manilatimes.net|access-date=2017-01-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906092112/http://www.manilatimes.net/visit-to-the-tzu-chi-foundation-in-taiwan/238309/|archive-date=6 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://globalnation.inquirer.net/114046/tzu-chi-foundation-lets-hear-it-for-amazing-buddhist-responders|title=Tzu Chi Foundation: Let’s hear it for amazing Buddhist responders|last=Petilla|first=Danny|website=globalnation.inquirer.net|access-date=2017-01-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116182921/https://globalnation.inquirer.net/114046/tzu-chi-foundation-lets-hear-it-for-amazing-buddhist-responders|archive-date=16 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Apart from being non-proselytist, Tzu Chi's adaptation of Buddhist principles is [[apolitical]].
In disaster regions where a particular religious faith is prominent, Tzu Chi regularly works together with local religious organizations. Tzu Chi has re-built [[mosques]] and [[church (building)|churches]] in disaster zones where faith plays an important role in local society.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PzdyNvcRTWk|title=Master Cheng Yen and Tzu Chi|publisher=The Discovery Channel|accessdate=15 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110210357/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PzdyNvcRTWk|archive-date=10 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Tzu Chi nuns ([[Bhikkhuni|bhikkhunis]]) do not rely on donations for their livelihood, something uncommon among most Buddhist orders. In earlier days, the nuns sustained themselves by farming, weaving and other handicrafts. More recently, they sustained themselves by the manufacture of electrical circuit breakers and other products.
===International branches===
Tzu Chi has branches in 47 countries and regions including USA, Canada, Australia, [[Thailand]], [[Indonesia]], Malaysia, [[Singapore]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Tzu Chi Singapore|url=https://zh-tw.facebook.com/tzuchisingapore|website=Facebook|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> and various locations in Asia, Europe and Africa.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tzuchi.org/global/offices/index.html | title=Tzu Chi Local Chapters and Associations | publisher=Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation | accessdate=29 December 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090404090834/http://www.tzuchi.org/GLOBAL/offices/index.html | archivedate=4 April 2009 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Television and Satellite Network===
On 17 August 1999, a television network was formed in Taiwan under the Tzu Chi Foundation of the Culture of Communication, Inc with the slogan "Love to make the world light up". Formally known as [[Da Ai Television]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Da Ai Television|url=http://www.daai.tv/daai-web/main/|publisher=Tzu Chi Culture and Communication Foundation|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020103914/http://www.daai.tv/daai-web/main/|archive-date=20 October 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> the network grew into a global broadcasting presence with offerings of a radio service,<ref>{{cite web|title=radio.newdaai.tv|url=http://radio.newdaai.tv/aod/index_in.php|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910195337/http://radio.newdaai.tv/aod/index_in.php|archive-date=10 September 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Tzu Chi Channel 1, Tzu Chi Channel 2, Da Ai TV Indonesia, Da Ai TV Thailand, and Da Ai TV Egypt. Live streaming of Channel 1 and 2 can also be found on YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|title=大愛電視一臺 Live 直播|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ukWk-Gy0NT8|website=Youtube|publisher=Tzu Chi DaAiVideo|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151220132054/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ukWk-Gy0NT8|archive-date=20 December 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Jing Si Books & Café===
Jing Si Books & Café is a chain of non-profit bookstores and cafes operated by Tzu Chi offering Tzu Chi merchandise and publications by [[Cheng Yen]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jing Si Books & Cafe|url=http://jingsi.com.tw/|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911002133/http://jingsi.com.tw/|archive-date=11 September 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Youth==
The Tzu Chi Collegiate Association (慈濟大專青年聯誼會) is the Foundation's college youth organization,<ref>{{cite web|title=Tzu Chi Collegiate Association (Singapore)|url=http://sgtzuching2014en.wordpress.com|website=慈濟大專青年聯誼會（新加坡）|publisher=WordPress.com|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910195926/http://sgtzuching2014en.wordpress.com/|archive-date=10 September 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and was officially established in Taiwan on 31 May 1992. With chapters at universities worldwide, its goal is to allow university students (known as Tzu Ching or 慈青, literally "compassionate youth") to be involved with Tzu Chi's activities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Singapore Tzu Ching 新加坡慈青|url=http://sgtzuching3in1.blogspot.sg|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911001701/http://sgtzuching3in1.blogspot.sg/|archive-date=11 September 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=What is Tzu Ching|url=http://www.umich.edu/~tzuching/|work=Tzu Chi Collegiate Association at the University of Michigan|publisher=[[University of Michigan]]|accessdate=22 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222213236/http://www.umich.edu/~tzuching/|archive-date=22 February 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Tzu Ching volunteers are given the opportunity to participate in large-scale events such as disaster relief and international NGO conferences such as the annual [[UN Youth Assembly]]. Master Cheng Yen encourages the Tzu Ching volunteers to actively communicate with each other, with the goals of learning and improving. Each year an international Tzu Ching officer training retreat camp is held at the foundation headquarters in [[Hualien City|Hualien]].
Tzu Shao (慈少) is the Tzu Chi branch for youths under the age of 18.
==Year End Ceremonies==
Each year Tzu Chi conducts a Year End Ceremony attended by Tzu Chi workers, volunteers and members in December where Master [[Cheng Yen]] distributes blessings in the form of red packets that embosses a coin in Taiwanese currency{{Refn|The coin symbolizes the fifty cents the thirty housewives saved at the founding of Tzu Chi|group=note}} together with auspicious words for the coming year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tzu Chi Year End Ceremony 2013|url=http://yeb.tzuchi.org.sg|accessdate=10 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910200034/http://yeb.tzuchi.org.sg/|archive-date=10 September 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox saint |name= Virgen de Copacabana |birth_date= |death_date= |feast_day=2 February
5 August |venerated_in= [[Roman Catholic Church]] ([[Bolivia]]) |image= Flickr - archer10 (Dennis) - Bolivia-113.jpg |imagesize= 300px |caption= Original statue of the Virgen de Copacabana in the Basilica |birth_place= |death_place= |titles=Our Lady of Copacabana
Most Blessed Virgin of the Candelaria
Queen and Patroness of Bolivia
La Coyeta |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes=[[Blessed Virgin Mary]], Inca dress and crown, [[Infant Jesus]], straw basket, pigeons, baton, gold Quechua jewelry |patronage=[[Bolivia]] and Bolivian people, [[Bolivian Navy]], National Police of Bolivia |major_shrine=[[Basilica of Our Lady of Copacabana]], Copacabana, Bolivia |suppressed_date= |issues= }} The '''Virgen de Copacabana''' (literal translation: '''Virgin of Copacabana'''; figurative translation: '''Our Lady of Copacabana'''; variant: '''Blessed Virgin of the Candelaria, Our Lady of Copacabana''') is the [[patron saint]] of [[Bolivia]]. She is [[venerate]]d in Bolivia during her feast day of 2 February, the day of the [[Purification of Mary]], or feast of the [[Virgin of Candelaria|Virgen de la Candelaria]]. She is also venerated on 5 August with her own liturgy and popular celebration. ==History== [[Copacabana, Bolivia|Copacabana]] is a Bolivian town located on a peninsula at the southeastern shore of [[Lake Titicaca]]. It is close to [[Isla del Sol]] and [[Isla de la Luna]], islands sacred to the [[Aymara people|Aymara]] and [[Quechua people|Quechua]]. In the mid 16th century, the inhabitants of Copacabana were divided into two groups: Anansayas, Inca newcomers, and Urinsayas, the traditional residents of the region. Despite conversion to Christianity, they continued an attachment to their original religion. Poor harvests lead them to consider attracting favor from heaven through a new confraternity. The Anansayas resolved to venerate the Virgin Mary while the Urinsayas selected [[Saint Sebastian|San Sebastian]].{{cite web|url=http://ojs.gc.cuny.edu/index.php/lljournal/rt/printerFriendly/257/221|title=An Indigenous Sculptor on the Spanish Stage: Calderón’s rewriting of Tito Yupanqui in ''La Aurora en Copacabana''|last=McCarl|first=Clayton |publisher=cuny.edu|accessdate=2009-08-11}} [[Image:Copacabana Bolivia06.jpg|thumb|right|Statue of the sculptor Francisco Tito Yupanqui.]] [[Francisco Tito Yupanqui]], an amateur sculptor, a descendant of the Inca [[Huayna Capac]], and a member of the Anansayas, did not abandon the idea. He decided to create an image of the [[Madonna (art)|Madonna]], believing it would influence the local people. Using clay, and assisted by his brother Philip, Francisco Tito created the image of the Virgin. The sculpture was placed at the side of the altar by the pastor, Father Antonio de Almedio. After Father Antonio left Copacabana, the priest Don Antonio Montoro took over. Unhappy with the look of the coarse and disproportionate sculpture, he ordered that it be removed from the altar and be placed in a corner of the [[sacristy]]. Francisco Tito was humbled by this setback. Advised by relatives, he went to [[Potosí|Potosi]] which had outstanding teachers of sacred image sculpting. While studying in the workshop of Maestro Diego Ortiz, Francisco Tito gained expertise in sculpture and in [[wood carving]]. With this skill, he resolved to create an improved image of the Candelaria. He looked through the churches of Potosí for an image of the Virgin which could serve as a model, finally finding the best one in the Convent of Santo Domingo to the Virgen del Rosario. He studied it closely to remember it before starting his new piece and held a Mass in honor of the [[Holy Trinity]] as a divine blessing for his work. The Urinsayas accepted the establishment of the Virgin Mary confraternity, but they did not accept Francisco Tito's carving, and decided to sell it. In La Paz, the picture reached the priest of Copacabana who decided he would bring the image to the people. On 2 February 1583, the image of Mary was brought to the hills of [[Guaçu]]. A series of miracles attributed to the icon made it one of the oldest [[Marian shrine]]s in the Americas, along with [[Our Lady of Guadalupe|Guadalupe]] in Mexico. On August 1, 1925, during the [[Papal]] visit of [[Pope Pius XI]] to Bolivia, the image of the Virgin of Copacabana was blessed and granted a [[canonical coronation]].https://books.google.com/books?id=ihujfu7oK7MC&pg=PA181&lpg=PA181&dq=our+lady+of+copacabana+canonical+coronation&source=bl&ots=p-X1lx_sXd&sig=njORxswKxAWs1p2uwi0t_xifUNU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_kuaS8rzNAhVDHh4KHQUvBDEQ6AEIQjAG#v=onepage&q=our%20lady%20of%20copacabana%20canonical%20coronation&f=falsehttp://catholicsaints.mobi/calendar/5-august.htmAttending the coronation were three Bolivian bishops, President [[Bautista Saavedra]] and ambassadors representing Argentina and Peru. ==Construction of the basilica== [[File:Church of copacabana.jpg|left|250px|Church of Copacabana]] From its beginning, the image gained a reputation for being a miracle. The [[Augustinians]] built their first chapel between the 1614 and 1618, and later, the Viceroy of [[Lima, Peru|Lima]], Conde de Lemos, morally and financially supported the construction of a [[basilica]] to honor the Virgin. Construction of the [[Basilica of Our Lady of Copacabana]] began in 1668, was inaugurated in 1678, and was completed by 1805. Subsequently, the faithful donated embellishments to the image, including valuable jewels, and the temple was filled with gifts and treasures. In 1825, when Bolivia gained independence, it was attributed to the faith of the population through the Virgin of Copacabana. However, in 1826, [[Antonio José de Sucre|Marshal Antonio José de Sucre]], the President of the Republic of Bolivia, expropriated all the jewels and colonial treasures at the Shrine of the Virgin, using them to create the first coins from Bolivia. ==Carving description== The body of the image measures about four feet, carved in [[Agave americana|maguey]] wood and is laminated in gold leaf. The clothes are that of an Inca princess. The form is covered with luxurious robes and dresses, and wears a wig of long, natural hair. It holds the Child Jesus in a peculiar position, as if about to fall. In her right hand, she holds a basket and a gold baton, a gift and souvenir of the visit in 1669 from the Viceroy of Peru. The original image never leaves the sanctuary; a copy is used for processions. Those leaving the shrine walk backwards with the intention not to turn their backs on the Virgin. ==Devotion in other countries== The Bolivian community in [[Argentina]] celebrates the Feast of the Virgin of Copacabana in [[Buenos Aires]] in October. ==April 2013 Robbery== In the early hours of Monday 22 April 2013 the sanctuary of Copacabana was robbed and the image of the Virgen de Copacabana was stripped of her gold and silver accessories.{{cite web|url=http://www.anonymousswisscollector.com/2013/04/the-virgin-of-copacabana-has-been-looted.html|title=The Virgin of Copacabana has been looted''|last=Yates|first=Donna|publisher=anonymousswisscollector.com|accessdate=2013-04-30}} Initial reports indicate that twenty-eight items, including the sculpture of the baby Jesus, were removed from the Virgen de Copacabana by thieves who entered the building using a ladder stolen from a nearby telecommunications station.{{cite web|url=http://www.la-razon.com/la_revista/tesoros-Virgen-carecen-seguro-antirrobo_0_1822617812.html|title= Los tesoros de la Virgen carecen de seguro antirrobo''|last=Linarez|first=Iblin|publisher=la-razon.com|accessdate=2013-04-30}} The Saturday 6 July 2013 the town of Copacabana restored the image of the Virgin with new jewelry.http://www.la-razon.com/la_revista/Virgen-Copacabana-nueva-corona-joyas_0_1864613572.html ==Further reading== *Alcalá, Luisa Elena. "Beginnings: Art, Time and Francisco Yupanqui's Virgin of Copacabana" in ''Arts of South America, 1492-1850'', ed. Donna Pierce, pp. 141-68. Denver: Denver Art Museum 2010. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ewtn.com/SPANISH/Maria/copacabana.htm Our Lady of Copacabana, Bolivia] {{es|lang}} * [http://www.noticiasfides.com/node/470799 Virgin of Copacabana, Patron Saint] {{es|lang}} * [http://www.copacabana-bolivia.com/copacabana/content/view/55/29/lang,es/ Virgin of Copacabana] {{es|lang}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090501052244/http://www.la-razon.com/versiones/20050904_005289/nota_277_199564.htm Copacabana: A Virgin venerated in Brazil] {{es|lang}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Copacabana, Virgen De}} [[Category:Virgin Mary in art]] [[Category:Titles of Mary]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Bolivia]] [[Category:Religion in Bolivia]] [[Category:Bolivian culture]]
