{{DISPLAYTITLE:Yuna (''Final Fantasy'')}} {{Good Article}} {{Infobox video game character | name=Yuna | image=Yuna.png | caption=Yuna in ''[[Final Fantasy X]]'', as illustrated by [[Tetsuya Nomura]] | series=''[[Final Fantasy]]'' | firstgame=''[[Final Fantasy X]]'' (2001) | creator=[[Motomu Toriyama]] | artist=[[Tetsuya Nomura]]
Tetsu Tsukamoto (''X-2'') | voiceactor={{Vgrelease|[[English language|EN]]|[[Hedy Burress]]|[[Japanese language|JP]]|[[Mayuko Aoki]]{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/2001/10/22/103,1003739823,1999,0,0.html|title=ティーダとユウナがCD発売記念イベントを開催!!|language=Japanese|publisher=Famitsu|date=October 22, 2001|accessdate=August 1, 2012}}}} |motionactor=Mayuko Aoki |inuniverse={{Final Fantasy character |weapon=Staff (''FFX'')
Guns (''FFX-2'') |race=Half [[Spira (Final Fantasy)#Al Bhed|Al Bhed]] |home=Besaid }}}} {{nihongo|'''Yuna'''|ユウナ|Yūna}} is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] from [[Square Enix]]'s ''[[Final Fantasy]]'' series. She was first introduced as the female [[protagonist]] and one of the main [[player character|playable characters]] of the 2001 [[role-playing video game]] ''[[Final Fantasy X]]'', appearing as a summoner embarking on a journey to defeat the world-threatening monster [[Sin (Final Fantasy X)|Sin]] alongside her companions, including the male protagonist [[Tidus]]. Yuna reappears in ''[[Final Fantasy X-2]]'', where she becomes the protagonist, searching for a way to find Tidus two years following his disappearance. Yuna has also been featured in other Square Enix games, notably ''[[Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy]]''. [[Tetsuya Nomura]] based Yuna's overall design on [[hakama]], but also wanted to give her outfit something that would flow and so gave her a [[furisode]]. Nomura said that her name means "night" in the [[Okinawan language]], which contrasts with Tidus' name, which is Okinawan for "sun". For ''Final Fantasy X-2'', the game's staff wanted Tetsu Tsukamoto to redesign her costume to reflect her personality and the game's atmosphere. Yuna's character was well received by many media critics and fans and in particular praised for her relationship to Tidus, as well as her characterization and [[sex appeal]]. Despite this positive reception, there was a mixed reception for her role in ''Final Fantasy X-2'' due to her redesign. ==Appearances== In ''[[Final Fantasy X]]'', Yuna is introduced as a summoner who can use healing magic and is able to summon powerful magical entities called [[Spira (Final Fantasy)|aeons]] with help from spirits known as Fayths.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=PlayStation 2|level=Besaid|quote='''Lulu:''' The fayth are people who gave their lives to battle Sin. Yevon took their souls, willingly given from their still-living bodies. / '''Tidus:''' Huh? / '''Lulu:''' Now they live forever trapped in statues. But when a summoner beckons, the souls of the fayth emerge once again. That's what we call an aeon. / '''Tidus:''' All that in this room? S-So what's Yuna doing in there? / '''Wakka:''' She prays with all her heart for a way to defeat Sin.}} Already known throughout Spira as the daughter of High Summoner [[Characters of Final Fantasy X and X-2#Braska|Braska]], who previously brought a brief respite from Sin's destruction ten years earlier, Yuna decides to embark on the summoner's pilgrimage to become a High Summoner herself.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=PlayStation 2|level=Besaid|quote='''Tidus''': We're taking the same boat as Yuna, right? Why do we gotta wait here? / '''Wakka''': Yuna came to this village ten years ago, when the last Calm started. ''[...]'' Since then, she's been like a little sister to me and Lulu. But she had the talent...she became an apprentice. Now, today, she leaves as a summoner. / '''Lulu''': This is our journey. We should leave together.}} Yuna must journey to temples across the world, acquire the aeon from each and summon the [[Spira (Final Fantasy)|Final Aeon]] in a battle that will kill them both.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=PlayStation 2|level=Bikanel Island - Home|quote='''Rikku''': The pilgrimages have to stop! If they don't, and they get to Zanarkand...they might defeat Sin. Yunie could...but then she... Yunie will die, you know?! You know, don't you? Summoners journey to get the Final Aeon. Yuna told you, didn't she? With the Final Aeon, she can beat Sin. But then...but then... If she calls it, the Final Aeon's going to kill her! Even if she defeats Sin, it will kill Yunie too, you know! / '''Tidus''': Was I the only one who didn't know...?}} She gradually becomes more open and falls in love with [[Tidus]].{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=PlayStation 2|Macalania Woods - Spring|quote='''Yuna:''' I'll continue. I must. If I give up now...I could do anything I wanted to, and yet... Even if I was with you, I could never forget. / '''Tidus:''' I'll go with you. I'm your guardian. Unless I'm...fired? / '''Yuna:''' Stay with me until the end. Please. / '''Tidus:''' Not until the end... Always. / '''Yuna:''' Always, then.}} Upon arriving at the place where Yuna can summon the final aeon, Tidus persuades the group to look for another way to defeat Sin without using any sacrifices.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Tidus:''' I give up. So what would an adult do, then? They know they can just throw away a summoner, then they can do whatever they like. You're right. I might not even have a chance. But no way am I gonna just stand here and let Yuna go. And what Auron said about there being a way... I think it's true. / '''Rikku:''' You'll think of something? / '''Tidus:''' I'll go ask Yunalesca. She's got to know something. / '''Rikku:''' You really think she'll help you? / '''Tidus:''' I don't know, but I have to try. This is my story. It'll go the way I want it...or I'll end it here. / '''Yuna:''' Wait. You say it's your story, but it's my story, too, you know? It would be so easy...to let my fate just carry me away...following this same path my whole life through. But I know...I can't. What I do, I do...with no regrets.}} After entering Sin's body, Yuna and her guardians defeat the disembodied spirit of [[Yu Yevon]], who is responsible for reviving Sin after each defeat, allowing an eternal Calm to start in Spira.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=[[PlayStation 2]]|level=Bevelle Temple|quote='''Tidus:''' We'll beat Yu Yevon. / '''Fayth''': If you defeat Yu Yevon, it will end. Tell me, what do you know about Yu Yevon? / '''Tidus''': He's what makes Sin come back! / '''Yuna''': Sin is his armor. It protects him. / '''Fayth''': Yu Yevon was once a summoner, long ago. He was peerless. Yet now he lives for one purpose: only to summon. ''[...]'' Even if you defeat[ed] Sin with the Final Summoning, Yu Yevon will live. Yu Yevon will join with the Final Aeon. He will transform it into a new Sin.}} However, Tidus disappears as he is the product of the Fayth, who could not depart until Sin's defeat.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=December 20, 2001 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Tidus:''' Yuna, I have to go. I'm sorry I couldn't show you Zanarkand. Goodbye! / '''Wakka:''' Hey! / '''Rikku:''' We're gonna see you again...? / ... / '''Yuna:''' I love you.}} In ''[[Final Fantasy X-2]]'', set two years after ''Final Fantasy X'', Yuna is a member of the [[Sphere Grid|sphere]] hunting group Gullwings, along with [[Rikku]] and [[Paine (Final Fantasy X-2)|Paine]]. In the game's [[international version]], the Gullwings go their separate ways before the game's opening, with Yuna returning to Besaid Island. The trio then reunite to explore a tower.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X-2: International + Last Mission |developer=Square |publisher=Square Enix |date=March 13, 2003|platform=PlayStation 2|level=Yadonoki Tower}} In ''X-2'', Yuna journeys to Spira in search of the truth behind a sphere containing a video featuring a man resembling Tidus in prison.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X-2 |developer=Square|publisher=[[Square Enix]] |date=March 13, 2003|platform=[[PlayStation 2]] |quote='''Yuna [voiceover]''': It all began when I saw this sphere of you. At least, it looked like you. I couldn't say for sure. I thought I might find more spheres like it if I joined the Gullwings. So I did. Oh, in case you're wondering, the Gullwings are sphere hunters, and sphere hunters are, well...this! We fly all over Spira. I'm really enjoying myself.}} During her journey, Yuna discovers the man from the sphere was actually [[Characters of Final Fantasy X and X-2#Shuyin|Shuyin]], a spirit who wishes to destroy Spira in revenge for the death of his lover, [[Characters of Final Fantasy X and X-2#Lenne|Lenne]].{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X-2 |developer=Square |publisher=Square Enix |date=2003-11-18 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Shuyin:''' Lenne. We disappeared together, but when I awoke, I was alone. I looked for you for so long. While I wandered, I realized something: Spira hasn't really changed at all. Everyone's still fighting over nothing. Still dying like they used to. A thousand years have passed, and they can't leave the hatred behind. I'm through waiting. I'll fix it. This world continues to fail us, and what's worse, I failed to protect you. Vegnagun will make that all go away. And we'll fade together again, together. Help me do it, Lenne.}} The Gullwings defeat Shuyin who departs to the afterlife with Lenne's spirit.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X-2|developer=Square |level=|quote='''Shuyin''': A thousand years, and this moment is all we get? / '''Lenne''': This moment's enough. I don't need anything else. Just knowing how you feel is enough. Shuyin, let's end this. Let's go home. /'''Shuyin''': Can we? / '''Lenne''': That was all a thousand years ago. We've come too far to look back now. Rest, Shuyin. Rest with me. Let's go. I have a new song for you.}} Depending on the player's progress throughout the game, the Fayth may revive Tidus so that she can reunite with him.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X-2 |developer=Square |publisher=Square Enix |date=March 13, 2003|platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Fayth:''' You heard it, didn't you? You want to see him? / '''Yuna:''' Him? / '''Fayth:''' Yes. You want to walk together again? / '''Yuna:''' Yes! / '''Fayth:''' I can't promise anything, but we'll do what we can.}}{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X-2 |developer=Square |publisher=Square Enix |date=March 13, 2003|platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Yuna:''' Are you real? / '''Tidus:''' I think so. Do I pass? / '''Yuna:''' You're back. / '''Tidus:''' I am back. I'm home. / '''Yuna:''' Welcome home.}} The HD Remastered version of the game adds a new audio drama where Yuna becomes a part of the group called Yevoners whose main temple is located on Besaid. In the story she breaks up with Tidus after telling him she loves somebody else before declaring she will fight Sin once again.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X - X-2 HD Remaster |developer=Square |publisher=Square Enix |date=March 18, 2014 |platform=PlayStation 3|quote=}} She also appears in ''[[Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy]]'', an action game that features several ''Final Fantasy'' characters, as one of the characters to be summoned by the goddess Cosmos to participate in a war against her rival Chaos. For this game, Yuna appears in her ''Final Fantasy X'' form but sightly arranged to fit with the game's cast.{{cite web|last=Gantayat|first=Anoop|url=http://andriasang.com/comtqv/nomura_other_games/|title=Hey Mr. Tetsuya Nomura, Whatchu Up To?|date=February 1, 2011|publisher=Andriasang|accessdate=June 14, 2012}} Additionally, she has an alternative design based on [[Yoshitaka Amano]]'s illustration, and a wedding dress from ''Final Fantasy X''.{{cite web|last=Gantayat|first=Anoop|url=http://andriasang.com/comtid/yuna_and_third_forms_dissidia_site/|title=Yuna and Many Third Forms at the Dissidia Duodecim Final Fantasy Official Site|date=January 21, 2011|publisher=Andriasang|accessdate=June 14, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Gantayat|first=Anoop|url=http://andriasang.com/comu4v/dissidia_gilgamesh_update/|title=Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy: Gilgamesh and More Another Forms|date=February 25, 2011|publisher=Andriasang|accessdate=June 14, 2012}} Her ''Final Fantasy X-2'' regular form was made available as [[downloadable content]].{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/comuzm/dissidia_vaan_yuna/|title=Pirate Vaan and Gunner Yuna Hit Dissidia Duodecim Final Fantasy Next Week|last=Gantayat|first=Anoop|date=April 14, 2011|publisher=Andriasang|accessdate=June 14, 2012}} Outside the ''Final Fantasy'' series, Yuna appears in ''[[Kingdom Hearts II]]'' as a pixie along with Paine and [[Rikku]]. Bribed by [[Maleficent]] into spying on [[Squall Leonhart|Leon]]'s group, the pixies eventually switch sides after being abandoned by the witch and told of [[Sora (Kingdom Hearts)|Sora]]'s cause.{{cite video game|title=Kingdom Hearts II|developer=Square Enix|level=|quote='''Yuna''': Where's Maleficent? / '''Sora''': Looks like she ran away. / ... / '''Sora''': Umm, hey...if you're looking to pick sides, why don't you pick Leon's? They can always use help. / '''Yuna''': Does this Leon have any treasure? / '''Donald''': Yeah, lots of stuff! / '''Rikku''': Perfect! /'''Paine''': Come on. / '''Sora''': Who ARE you? / '''Yuna''': Oh, we're nothing worth mentioning. / '''Paine''': Just three treasure fanatics.}} Yuna is also featured in the board game style video game ''[[Itadaki Street#Itadaki Street Special|Itadaki Street Special]]'', appearing alongside Auron and Tidus,{{cite web| url = http://www.square-enix.co.jp/games/ps2/itastsp/| language = Japanese| title = ドラゴンクエスト＆ファイナルファンタジー in いただきストリート Special| publisher = Square Enix| accessdate = March 13, 2008}} and represents ''Final Fantasy X'' in the rhythm game ''[[Theatrhythm Final Fantasy]]''.{{cite web| last=Yip|first=Spencer|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2011/11/12/aerith-snow-vivi-and-faris-are-in-theatrhythm-final-fantasy-too/ |title=Aerith, Snow, Vivi, And Faris Are In Theatrhythm: Final Fantasy Too|publisher=Siliconera|author= |date=November 12, 2011 |accessdate=June 30, 2012}} Multiple figures and figurines of Yuna were produced by various manufacturers,{{cite web|url=http://myfigurecollection.net/search.php?character_strict=1&character_id=1742|title=Yuna|publisher=MyFigureCollection.net|accessdate=August 2, 2012}} including a 2001 figure by Square.{{cite web |title=Square Unveils Final Fantasy X Figures |url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/095/095828p1.html |work=IGN|publisher=News Corporation |accessdate=December 24, 2009 |date=June 14, 2001}} A 2003 audio CD ''[[Music of Final Fantasy X-2#Final Fantasy X-2 Vocal Collection|Final Fantasy X-2 Vocal Collections]]'' features performances by [[Mayuko Aoki]], [[Marika Matsumoto]] and [[Megumi Toyoguchi]], the voice actresses for Yuna, Rikku and Paine, respectively.{{cite web |title=Yuna, Pine and Rikku Make Music Debuts |url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/425/425217p1.html |publisher=IGN |accessdate=December 24, 2009 |date=June 20, 2003}}{{cite web | author=Gann, Patrick | title=Final Fantasy X-2 Vocal Collection - Paine | url=http://rpgfan.com/soundtracks/ffx-2-paine/index.html | publisher=RPGFan | accessdate=August 2, 2012}}{{cite web | author=Gann, Patrick | title=Final Fantasy X-2 Vocal Collection - Rikku | url=http://rpgfan.com/soundtracks/ffx-2-rikku/index.html | publisher=RPGFan | accessdate=August 2, 2012}}{{cite web | author=Gann, Patrick | title=Final Fantasy X-2 Vocal Collection - Yuna | url=http://rpgfan.com/soundtracks/ffx-2-yuna/index.html | publisher=RPGFan | accessdate=August 2, 2012}} ==Creation and development== According to [[Tetsuya Nomura]], he based Yuna's overall design on [[hakama]], a type of traditional Japanese clothing. Nomura said that when he learned the character was to perform a dance called the "[[Spira (Final Fantasy)#Death and afterlife|sending]]," he wanted to give her outfit something that would flow. For this reason, the specific type of [[kimono]] he chose for her was a [[furisode]], a long-sleeved kimono.{{cite web | author=Knight, Sheila | date=December 13, 2003| title=Tetsuya Nomura 20s | url=http://flaregamer.com/b2article.php?p=81&more=1 | publisher=FLAREgamer | accessdate=April 13, 2006}} Nomura also said that he adorned Yuna's dress and necklace with images of the [[hibiscus]] flower also called "yuna," and that her name carries the meaning of "night" (夕な) in [[Okinawan language|Okinawan]], establishing a contrast between her and the lead male protagonist of ''Final Fantasy X'', Tidus, whose Japanese name (ティーダ) translates to "sun" (太陽) in Okinawan. This contrast is also represented in-game by items named for the sun and moon that empower Tidus' and Yuna's most powerful weapons. Nomura explains that while all these subtle details may be unneeded, he wanted his designs to have meaning behind them. [[File:Yuna FFX-2.png|thumb|left|upright|Yuna's re-design for ''[[Final Fantasy X-2]]'']] The positive fan reaction to ''Final Fantasy X'' convinced the developers to continue the story of Yuna and other characters with ''Final Fantasy X-2''. Costume designer Tetsu Tsukamoto said that the radical design changes for Yuna from one game to the other reflected a huge cultural change. Producer Yoshinori Kitase added that they did not want to make ''Final Fantasy X-2'' feel like an extension of its predecessor, so they changed the clothing of Yuna, Rikku and others' to make them seem more active. This was accomplished before the story and setting were created. Because Yuna, Rikku and Paine live in a more care-free world, the designers wanted them to be able to dress up, a feature which became key to the gameplay. Scenario writer [[Kazushige Nojima]] described her new outfit as a "natural reaction to the heavy stuff she wore in ''FFX''." Yuna's singing performance was used to demonstrate the pop feel that the game incorporates.{{cite web |title=Final Fantasy X-2 Developer Interview |url=http://uk.ps2.ign.com/articles/442/442025p1.html |work=IGN|publisher=News Corporation |accessdate=August 2, 2012|date=November 25, 2003}}{{cite web |title=More Final Fantasy X-2 Details |url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/26766/more-final-fantasy-x-2-details/ |publisher=GamePro |accessdate=December 24, 2009 |date=October 23, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607145223/http://www.gamepro.com/article/news/26766/more-final-fantasy-x-2-details/|archivedate=June 7, 2011}} ''Final Fantasy X'' director [[Motomu Toriyama]] said her personality was the result of not having her bear the responsibility of being a summoner anymore. He added that while "she could be seen as a completely different person, ... deep in her heart, she is the same old Yuna."{{cite web|author=Dunham, Jeremy |title=Exclusive interview: Final Fantasy X-2 |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/exclusive-interview-final-fantasy-x-2/ |publisher=GamesRadar |date=March 9, 2004 |accessdate=June 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131114122727/http://www.gamesradar.com/exclusive-interview-final-fantasy-x-2/ |archivedate=November 14, 2013 |df= }} In the Japanese versions of the games Yuna has been voiced by [[Mayuko Aoki]]. [[Hedy Burress]] provides the character's voice in the English adaptations of the game. In voicing Yuna, Burress remembers trying to translate Yuna's duty, respect and honor, but also wanting to retain the gentleness and femininity of her character. When commenting on how the audiences would react to ''Final Fantasy X'', Burress said that she wanted them to participate in the game itself and to "transport them into a completely different world" through the voices.{{cite video game|title=Final Fantasy X International |developer=Square |publisher=Square EA |date=January 31, 2002|platform=PlayStation 2|level=Beyond Final Fantasy: Voices}} ==Reception== Yuna received positive critical reception for her appearance in ''Final Fantasy X''. Chris Reiter of Gaming Target ranked her as the third best "[[PlayStation 2]] babe", describing her as "the star heroine whose soft features, kindness, and her unique story makes her one of the better beauties to love."Chris Reiter, [http://www.gamingtarget.com/article.php?artid=4726 PlayStation 2: Heroes, Villains, Babes, and Bad Boys - Part 2], Gaming Target, October 28, 2005. In 2008, ''[[Chip (magazine)|Chip]]'' ranked her as the 13th top "girl of gaming".{{cite web|url=http://download.chip.eu/en/Top-20-Girls-of-Gaming_1505633.html?tab=5&show=7 |title=Top 20 Girls of Gaming - Gallery 7 - EN |publisher=Download.CHIP.eu |date=August 22, 2008 |accessdate=2013-11-21}} In 2012, Larry Hester of ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' ranked the original version of Yuna as the 20th "hottest" video game character yet.{{cite web|last=Hester|first=Larry|url=http://www.complex.com/video-games/2012/06/the-50-hottest-video-game-characters/yuna|title=The 50 Hottest Video Game Characters|publisher=Complex.com|date=June 27, 2012|accessdate=August 2, 2012}} That same year, Heath Hooker of GameZone ranked Yuna the ninth top ''Final Fantasy'' character, calling her "one of the strongest female characters in the entire ''Final Fantasy'' franchise" and stating "the depth of character Yuna presents to the player is unfathomable and is one reason why she lands on this list."{{cite web|last=Hooker |first=Heath |url=http://www.gamezone.com/originals/2012/01/01/top-10-final-fantasy-characters |title=Top 10 Final Fantasy Characters |publisher=GameZone |date=2012-01-01 |accessdate=2014-07-05}} In 2013, ''Complex'' editors Michael Rougeau and Gus Turner listed Yuna at number 21 on the list of the greatest heroines in video game history.{{cite web|last=Rougeau|first=Michael|url=http://www.complex.com/video-games/2013/01/the-50-greatest-heroines-in-video-game-history/yuna|title=50 Greatest Heroines In Video Game History|publisher=Complex|date=March 4, 2013|accessdate=March 24, 2013}} ranked Yuna as the sixth greatest ''Final Fantasy'' character of all time.{{cite web|author=Gus Turner|url=http://www.complex.com/video-games/2013/10/greatest-final-fantasy-characters-all-time/yuna |title=Yuna — The 20 Greatest Final Fantasy Characters of All Time |publisher=Complex |date=2013-10-08 |accessdate=2013-11-22}} However, [[PSU.com]] retrospectively called Yuna an underrated character and stated that she was overlooked due to [[Auron (Final Fantasy)|Auron]] and Rikku.{{cite web|url=http://www.psu.com/a013783/In-the-Spotlight--Yuna|title=In the Spotlight: Yuna|author=PSU Community|publisher=PlayStation Universe|date=December 1, 2011|accessdate=August 2, 2012}} GamesRadar listed Yuna as one of the 25 best new characters of the 2000s, describing the romance between her and Tidus as "legendary" and Yuna herself as compassionate, generous and dutiful.{{cite web |title=The 25 best new characters of the decade |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/the-25-best-new-characters-of-the-decade/?page=5 |publisher=GamesRadar |accessdate=January 4, 2010|date=December 29, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308144404/http://www.gamesradar.com/the-25-best-new-characters-of-the-decade/?page=5| archivedate=March 8, 2014}} Yuna and Tidus were included on the list of "great loves" by Matthew Rorie of [[GameSpot]] in 2006,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/features/great-loves-6144012/?page=5|title=Great Loves, Page 5|last=Rorie|first=Matthew|date=February 14, 2006|work=GameSpot|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=August 2, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304015049/http://www.gamespot.com/articles/great-loves/1100-6144012/|archivedate=2014-03-04 }} while AJ Glasser of [[GamesRadar]] in 2008 listed them as the second best Square Enix couple.{{cite web| url = http://www.gamesradar.com/top-10-square-enix-couples/?page=9 | title = Top 10 Square Enix Couples| publisher = GamesRadar| author=Glasser, AJ| accessdate = June 24, 2010}} Their kiss scene was declared as number two best in video games by [[Lisa Foiles]] of ''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'',{{cite web|author=Lisa Foiles |url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/top-5-with-lisa-foiles/8639-Top-5-Videogame-Kisses |title=Top 5 Videogame Kisses | Top 5 with Lisa Foiles Video Gallery | The Escapist |publisher=Escapistmagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-19}} and Yuna's abortive wedding with Seymour was also ranked as the third memorable matrimony in the history of [[PlayStation]] by ''[[Official PlayStation Magazine (UK)|Official PlayStation Magazine]]'' in 2014.''Official PlayStation Magazine UK'' 92 (January 2014), page 30. Yuna's design change in ''Final Fantasy X-2'' received a mixed reception. Rob Wright of [[Tom's Hardware]] included her among the 50 greatest female characters in video game history.{{cite web|url=http://www.tomsgames.com/us/2007/02/20/the_50_greatest_female_characters_in_the_history_of_video_games/page10.html|last=Wright|first=Rob|title=The 50 Greatest Female Characters in Video Game History|publisher=Tom's Games|date=February 20, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080120115214/http://www.tomsgames.com/us/2007/02/20/the_50_greatest_female_characters_in_the_history_of_video_games/page10.html|archivedate=January 20, 2008|accessdate=August 2, 2012}} Jeremy Dunham of [[IGN]] praised the clothing designs, combining "proven and recognizable ''Final Fantasy'' styles" with a "revealing neo-modern fashion sense", referencing her warrior costume as a stand-out, and also said that English voice actress [[Hedy Burress]]' portrayal seemed more comfortable as opposed to the previous game.{{cite web|last=Dunham |first=Jeremy |title=Final Fantasy X-2 -
